text: findings the general court finds scientific evidence for the warming of the climate system is unequivocal this warming is overwhelmingly attributable to human activity and development particularly the combustion of fossil fuels left unchecked the climate crisis will continue to have real and catastrophic impacts on new hampshire s residents economy and environment as well as on the health and safety of new hampshire families a new hampshire will see longer and hotter summers shorter warmer winters and more frequent and more extreme precipitation events resulting in both increase flooding and drought b climate impacts will endanger the health of new hampshire families by facilitating the spread of diseases as well as increasing rates of respiratory and cardiovascular disease c increased warming and more extreme and more frequent precipitation events will also negatively impact key sectors of new hampshire s economy harming agriculture tourism and outdoor recreational activities such as skiing hiking fishing and hunting d a warmer and more acidic gulf of maine will see increased coastal flooding which will endanger the lives homes and business properties of coastal residents e decreases in terrestrial and aquatic biodiversity and wildlife and fishing stocks brought on by climate change and overdevelopment will likewise imperil new hampshire s fishing hunting hiking and related industries and the local economies and communities that depend upon them taking action to mitigate the climate crisis also presents opportunities for new hampshire and the state should move quickly to maximize the of mitigating climate disruption a as renewable resources like wind and solar increasingly replace fossil fuels new hampshire manufacturing businesses should reap the benefits the state should act to ensure new hampshire is in the effort to harvest the wind resources of the gulf of maine and to benefit from supply chains b in addition to helping reduce the state s greenhouse gas emissions replacing fossil fuels with zero emission sources of energy will also improve the health of new hampshire families by reducing pollution that degrades the state s air quality c producing energy from local wind water and solar facilities will keep billions of our energy dollars in state instead of sending them out of state and out of the country creating a virtuous circle of development d a more and energy state government will save taxpayer s money and retain more of that money in state to fuel new hampshire s economy e it is incumbent upon the state government to take prompt proactive and continuing action to protect residents from the anticipated consequences of the climate crisis to mitigate the foreseeable harms to the extent possible and to safeguard energy policy rsa is repealed and reenacted to read as follows new hampshire energy policy the general court declares that it shall be the energy policy of this state to a meet the energy needs of the citizens and businesses of the state at the lowest reasonable cost while providing for the reliability and diversity of energy sources b maximize the use of all energy efficiency and other resources c achieve the greenhouse gas emission goals identified in rsa i and d protect the safety and health of the citizens the physical environment of the state and the supply of natural resources for future generations the energy policy of this state shall be developed with due regard and appreciation for both the and financial and fiscal costs imposed by climate change on the state its citizens and
